summary: In Regina v. Arthur and Others, applications for attachment orders were brought before the Divisional Court in Accra for alleged criminal contempt of the Divisional Court in Kumasi, arising from newspaper articles published during pending proceedings. The court held that only the court in which the contempt is alleged to have occurred has jurisdiction to hear such applications. Relying on precedent and Section 7 of the Courts Ordinance, c. 4 of 1951, the court ruled that although the Chief Justice has nationwide jurisdiction, this does not empower a court in one judicial division to hear contempt matters belonging to another. Therefore, the Accra court lacked jurisdiction, and the applications were refused.
verdict: Applications for attachment orders refused due to lack of jurisdiction.

jurisdiction.court: High Court, Eastern Judicial Division, Divisional Court

citations: In the Matter of an Application for Attachment for Contempt of Court (1886) 2 T.L.R. 351
rationaleHighlights: Only the court in respect of which contempt is alleged has jurisdiction to hear attachment applications.
The Chief Justice's nationwide jurisdiction does not allow hearing matters in a court lacking jurisdiction.
Precedent from 1886 supports that courts punish only contempt of themselves.
Section 7 of the Courts Ordinance does not confer jurisdiction on a Divisional Court outside the territorial division where the contempt occurred.
